item.title: Deploy Hugo on Github Pages With Travis CI
item.description: Getting started with Hugo is very interesting especially when you are new to static site generators. Just run hugo serve and your markdown files are converted into a website. But, when it comes deployment it’s really painful if you’re doing it manually and it’s more painful when you have to do the whole process all over again just to fix a stupid typo. In my previous post - Setting Up Hugo on GitHub Pages, I talked about hosting Hugo sites on GitHub pages and one of the reason for doing so was Travis CI.

item.title: Setting Up Hugo on GitHub Pages
item.description: Recently I started learning GoLang and came across Hugo which is an open source and the fastest static site generator. Before migrating to Hugo this blog was on self-hosted Ghost on DigitalOcean. Ghost is a minimal and straightforward blogging platform which is more into WordPress, Medium or Tumblr league because it comes with a really beautiful admin panel. For shell lovers Jekyll, Hugo, Hexo and many other static site generators are no-nonsense tools for quickly spinning up “portfolio-cum-personal-blog” type websites.
